description: 16th century, borrowed from Dutch tragelen (“to pull with a towline, trawl”), from Middle Dutch traghelen, from traghel (“dragnet”) (presumably from Latin tragula (“dragnet”)), and as such root-cognate with English drag.

entries.meaning: A net or dragnet used for trawling. [from the 16th c.]
A long fishing line having many short lines bearing hooks attached to it; a setline.

verbs.description: trawl (third-person singular simple present trawls, present participle trawling, simple past and past participle trawled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To take (fish or other marine animals) with a trawl.
(intransitive) To fish from a slow-moving boat.
(intransitive) To make an exhaustive search for something within a defined area.
